title: Earth 2200 AD: The Unseen Realms

introduction.setting: Earth in the year 2200 is a marvel of technology — megacities, orbital stations, AI-driven economies, and colonies stretching toward Mars. Humanity believes it has conquered the planet.
introduction.hidden_truth: Below, above, and alongside them live civilizations unseen: elves hidden in forests, dwarves beneath mountains, kitsune in shrines and cities, beastfolk roaming wilderness and alleys, fey courts in dimensional folds, and dragons slumbering in oceans and skies.
introduction.tone: The world teeters on the edge of discovery. Nothing has broken yet — but everything could.

elves.agenda: Preserve Earth’s wilds; fractured between isolationist Keepers, human-aiding Reformers, and the militant Verdant Circle.

dwarves.agenda: Maintain secrecy while subtly fueling humanity’s industries with miracle alloys; some wish to reclaim the surface as a dwarven dominion.

kitsune.agenda: Tricksters, guardians, and predators. Ancient clans debate their place in a modern world — conceal, conquer, or coexist.

domains: war-torn frontiers where human cruelty thrives
lycans.agenda: Survival and unity; once divided into packs of rage and restraint, now dreaming of a shared moonlit nation.

domains: ancient temple cities buried beneath sand
felinari.agenda: Seek balance between pride and independence; legends speak of a ‘Golden Pride’ that will unify the scattered tribes.

ursans.agenda: Preserve the Old Ways. The Ursans act as living memory-keepers of the primordial age, resisting both human encroachment and fey influence.

avians.agenda: Divided between the Skyward Creed who guide humanity and the Tempest Flock who wish to purge it.

dragons.agenda: Sleep, watch, judge. The awakening of even one would shift the world’s balance; ancient covenants keep them dreaming — for now.

domains: Dimensional pockets accessed through thresholds — old tunnels, forests, mirrors
fey_courts.agenda: Perpetual intrigue and chaos; the Seelie seek balance, the Unseelie seek amusement — both feed on mortal wonder and fear.

merfolk.agenda: Reclaim the drowned lands of myth. Some trade with humans, others sabotage coastal empires that pollute their realm.

domains: abandoned oilfields saturated with aether residue
djinn.agenda: Seek liberation from ancient seals; their pacts echo still through modern corporate ‘contracts’ written in unseen ink.

necrolites.agenda: Bridge life and death, arguing that mortality is obsolete; opposed fiercely by the Church and by the Fey.

magic.nature: A natural force bound into matter, emotion, and will.
disciplines: Elemental Binding — command over fire, storm, stone, and water
Spirit Pacts — calling ancestral or primal entities
Runic Craft — encoding essence into machines, tools, or weapons
Shapecraft — healing, shapeshifting, altering one’s body
magic.traces: Magic leaves visible signs: storms, strange lights, broken machines. It is not subtle when wielded strongly.

factions_and_politics.concord_of_silence: A fragile pact between elves, dwarves, kitsune, and beastfolk to remain hidden from humanity.
factions_and_politics.shattered_courts: Fey refuse the Concord, meddling openly in mortal affairs.
factions_and_politics.rogues: Vampiric covens, cults, and beastfolk war-bands defy all treaties, feeding on human populations.
factions_and_politics.F.E.A.R: Foundation for Ethereal Affairs & Regulation, A global faction founded as a type of police force between humans and all others. they are on the side of peace, not human or magic folk. F.E.A.R Agents are called Shades

story_hooks: The First Contact — A human probe finds a magical being under Europa’s ice.
The Blood Market — Vampires open black markets for human lifeforce.
The Shardfall — A crystal of unknown origin crashes into the Pacific.
The Rising Storm — Weather begins behaving as though guided by intent.
The Awakened AI — A corporate AI awakens with magical abilities.
The Hidden City — Construction uncovers a dwarven metropolis.
The Fox Oath — Kitsune clans debate revealing themselves to humanity.
The Forgotten Gate — A subway tunnel exposes a dormant Fey portal.
The Beast Rebellion — Beastfolk tribes gather under one banner.
The Sleeping Dragon — A dragon beneath a volcano begins to stir.
The Soulforge — Dwarves attempt to create synthetic souls.
The Eclipse Pact — A cosmic alignment where bargains reshape reality.
The Ocean’s Secret — Something vast moves in the Mariana Trench.
The Human Mage — A human child is born able to wield magic freely.
The Broken Concord — Some factions push to end magical secrecy.
The Fey Market — A Fey bazaar materializes in a megacity.
The Spirit Eclipse — Ghosts manifest visibly across Earth.
The Alloy War — Rival dwarven clans weaponize enchanted tech.
The Kitsune Flame — Prophecy speaks of a fox-spirit igniting the world.
The Celestial Return — Ancient star-beings announce their return.

campaign_tools.tone: Urban fantasy blended with cyberpunk and myth.
player_roles: Hybrids or outliers bridging both worlds
Agents of factions trying to steer outcomes

monsters.name: Shadow Hounds
monsters.description: Beastlike predators born of fear, hunting in urban ruins.

monsters.name: Whisper Shades
monsters.description: Ghostly entities that feed on memory and attention.

monsters.name: Leviathans
monsters.description: Ancient ocean titans mistaken for tectonic movement.

monsters.name: Ironfang Packs
monsters.description: Corrupted beastfolk consumed by rage and bloodlust.

monsters.name: Neon Wraiths
monsters.description: Light-born phantoms that ride along signage and holo-billboards, stepping out when the power flickers.

monsters.name: Glass Seraphs
monsters.description: Shattered-window angels that assemble from city debris; protective until startled, then razor-fast.

monsters.name: Rust Wyrms
monsters.description: Serpentine colonies of nanofleas that eat oxidation and metal fatigue, hollowing vehicles and bridges.

monsters.name: Circuit Lurkers
monsters.description: Gremlin-like sprites living inside old grids; short out sensors and make doors forget how to open.

monsters.name: Ember Moths
monsters.description: Palm-sized fire-kissed moths that drink heat; harmless alone, but swarms can blackout districts.

monsters.name: Null Bloom
monsters.description: Static-white flowers that unfold in midair; their pollen erases recent memories for a few minutes.

monsters.name: Skylight Krakens
monsters.description: Tangle-limbed cloud-beasts seen during electrical storms; descend as ropes of mist that lift stragglers.

monsters.name: Gutter Saints
monsters.description: Hooded silhouettes that clean blood and graffiti at night; gentle until their ritual path is blocked.

monsters.name: Dream Masons
monsters.description: Invisible architects that rearrange alleys and stairwells while you sleep, shifting city geometry.

monsters.name: Bone Choir
monsters.description: Harmless birdlike shells that mimic sirens and lullabies; prolonged listening induces dangerous sleepwalking.

monsters.name: Iron Widows
monsters.description: Street-sculpture spiders that weave cables into traps; territorial around substations and rail yards.

monsters.name: Ozone Priests
monsters.description: Blue-robed figures seen ahead of heat lightning; they bless rooftops, then call winds that knock climbers down.

monsters.name: Mirror Jackals
monsters.description: Predators that exist only in reflections; drag victims a step ‘sideways’ if chased into mirror-lit halls.

monsters.name: Tide Apostles
monsters.description: Salt-encrusted walkers from storm drains; speak in wave-pattern rhythms that lure listeners toward seawalls.

monsters.name: Cinder Drakes
monsters.description: Wingless rooftop lizards that vent hot ash; spark rooftop fires when nesting is disturbed.

monsters.name: Paper Wolves
monsters.description: Origami canids animated by unresolved letters; track the names inked on their folded hides.

monsters.name: Lantern Brides
monsters.description: Tall figures with lanterns for heads; guide the lost to safety—or to places they need to confront.

monsters.name: Subsonic Crows
monsters.description: Murder flocks whose wingbeats carry infrasound; cause nausea, vertigo, and poor decisions in crowds.

monsters.name: Pavement Leviers
monsters.description: Burrowing slabs that ‘breathe’ under streets, shifting manholes and tripping patrols.

monsters.name: Hollow Kings
monsters.description: Abandoned exo-suits that believe they still rule; enforce imaginary curfews with recorded decrees.

monsters.name: Mossback Torto
monsters.description: Peaceful beastfolk—slow-speaking tortoise elders who tend rooftop gardens and trade herbal remedies.

monsters.name: Willow Hinds
monsters.description: Peaceful beastfolk—deer-kin caretakers of shrine groves; guide travelers if treated with courtesy.

monsters.name: Coast Otter Clans
monsters.description: Peaceful beastfolk—playful river and harbor foragers; skilled at salvage and knot-lore.

monsters.name: Stone Badgers
monsters.description: Peaceful beastfolk—burrow-builders who reinforce tunnels and stabilize quake-damaged blocks.

monsters.name: Skylark Sprites
monsters.description: Peaceful beastfolk—avian-lilt messengers who relay news between rooftops; wary but friendly.

monsters.name: Sunmane Lions
monsters.description: Peaceful beastfolk—honor-bound lion-kin who mediate disputes; intervene only to stop cruelty.

monsters.name: River Pangolins
monsters.description: Peaceful beastfolk—scale-plated archivists who ferry seedbanks and repair flood wards.

monsters.name: Lantern Foxes
monsters.description: Peaceful beastfolk—small fox-kin with bioluminescent tails; light evacuation routes in storms.

monsters.name: Ironfang Berserkers
monsters.description: Angry beastfolk—rage-sick offshoot of wolf-kin; strike in frenzied packs when blood is spilled.

monsters.name: Cinderboar Sounders
monsters.description: Angry beastfolk—boar-kin with furnace breath; charge lines and topple barricades when provoked.

monsters.name: Glass Jackals
monsters.description: Angry beastfolk—jackal-kin with shard-bright eyes; scavenger tacticians that test perimeters nightly.

monsters.name: Razor Kites
monsters.description: Angry beastfolk—kite-bird raiders who dive-bomb lanterns and steal supplies mid-flight.

monsters.name: Grudge Bears
monsters.description: Angry beastfolk—bear-kin who keep old hurts like ledgers; smash toll gates and tithe posts.

monsters.name: Thorn Martens
monsters.description: Angry beastfolk—tree-line skirmishers that lay snare-vines and harry patrols at dusk.

monsters.name: Salt Hyenas
monsters.description: Angry beastfolk—coastline raiders with brine-crusted manes; laugh-screams unsettle guards.

monsters.name: Soot Ram Herds
monsters.description: Angry beastfolk—smoke-horned rams that stampede through foundries when sirens wail.

map_concepts.undercities: Dwarven forges and lost human sub-levels beneath megacities.
map_concepts.hidden_forests: Bio-shielded elf sanctuaries where trees glow with living light.
map_concepts.fey_thresholds: Doorways in urban alleys, abandoned stations, and deep woods that lead to alien courts.
map_concepts.leviathan_graveyards: Storm-locked ocean tracts littered with bones the size of towers; currents behave like nervous systems.
map_concepts.sky_archipelagos: Floating isles anchored to ancient wards; accessible by storm elevators and dragon thermals.
map_concepts.ghostnet_reefs: Sunken fiber-optic webs colonized by mer engineers and bioluminescent polyps.
map_concepts.iron_veins: Planet-spanning rail-tunnels that the dwarves call the World-Stitch; some lines move when unobserved.
map_concepts.moon_sanctums: Coldlight observatories tended by sphinxes; riddles map the safest nights to cross court borders.
map_concepts.ember_routes: Volcanic caravan paths protected by salamander guilds; heat mirages hide oasis-markets.
map_concepts.echo_bazaars: Markets that appear in the same plaza across multiple cities at once; trade is bound by oath-chimes.
map_concepts.titan_steps: Giant-made switchbacks carved into mountain faces; each step is a village terrace.
map_concepts.storm_corridors: Predictable lightning highways used by avian couriers and sky-whales during migration.
map_concepts.mirror_metros: Transit lines that run inside reflections; tickets are polished silver and names are written backwards.

elves.rivalries: Reformist elves clash with isolationist elders.
elves.secrets: They maintain living trees older than human civilization.

dwarves.rivalries: Clan Emberforge vs Clan Deepdelve over control of rune-tech.
dwarves.secrets: They control rare alloys critical to human aerospace tech.

leaders: Lady Itsuko of the Red Flame
kitsune.secrets: Some infiltrate human governments as advisors.

fey.rivalries: Endless courtly wars of trickery and betrayal.
fey.secrets: They may have seeded humanity’s myths to control them.

merfolk.rivalries: Harbor clans feud with deep-trench monastery schools over contact with surface trade.
merfolk.secrets: They can read data-ghosts lingering in undersea cables like scripture.

dragons.rivalries: Old hoardlords vs young venture-drakes on whether wealth is gold or information.
dragons.secrets: Some ‘extinct’ flights exist as corporate holding companies with airspace charters.

leaders: Matron Basalt of the Deep Strata
giants.rivalries: Sky-born cloud giants disdain stone-born titans for ‘crawling’ politics.
giants.secrets: They terraform by humming—mountain resonance shifts weather over seasons.

goblins.rivalries: Tinker guilds vs street syndicates over salvage rights.
goblins.secrets: They hide the fail-safes for two megacity power grids inside children’s wind-up toys.

dryads.rivalries: Urban park-spirits resent old-growth matrons for ‘hoarding’ sap routes.
dryads.secrets: They can migrate a forest single-tree-at-a-time along subway medians.

leaders: Countess Vespara of the Violet Gate
nocturnals.rivalries: Ethical hemovores vs predators who treat cities as farms.
nocturnals.secrets: They engineered synthetic vitae centuries ago but suppress it to control politics.

therian_clans.rivalries: Wolves, panthers, and bears argue over ward-patrol doctrine and human alliances.
therian_clans.secrets: Moon-rituals are a cover; true trigger is infrasound buried in city sirens.

leaders: General Narkesh of the Seven Helms
naga.rivalries: Temple guardians vs militant river legions over interventionism.
naga.secrets: Their ‘curse’ is voluntary—shedding to change identities in plain sight.

avians.rivalries: Courier guilds vs sky-priests over control of storm corridors.
avians.secrets: They map lightning like rail timetables and can predict strikes to the second.

selkies.rivalries: Family pods feud with mercantile brokers over pelt-rite traditions.
selkies.secrets: They run witness-protection ‘harbors’ by loaning skins and new names.

salamanders.rivalries: Forge orders vs ascetic fire-walkers on whether flame is tool or teacher.
salamanders.secrets: They can smelt memory into glass beads that replay moments when warmed.

leaders: Regent Nebu of Sand and Code
sphinx_conclave.rivalries: Traditional riddle-law vs modern ‘captcha courts’ that adjudicate digital oaths.
sphinx_conclave.secrets: They maintain a hidden ledger of true names that can unlock fey thresholds safely.

tanuki_consortium.rivalries: Prank cooperatives vs sober accountants over how much chaos is ‘good business.’
tanuki_consortium.secrets: They own 11% of vending machines in the Eastern Bloc—every third is a disguised gatekeeper.

djinn.rivalries: Free-wind courts vs bound-contract houses over wish ethics.
djinn.secrets: Most ‘three-wish’ myths are NDAs; real bargains are amortized across generations.
